content.description: A right leaning seam that meets up with the two other climbs sharing its anchor sitch ("Old Guys with the Shakes" and "Mothers and Fathers"), Radical Right is typified by a slightly run out protection scheme, some crystalline jugs, and the tendency to climb more like a face climb than a crack.
content.protection: Finger pieces up to 2", a two bolt anchor.
content.location: Just left of "Old Guys with the Shakes".

climbs.name: Old Guys With The Shakes
climbs.fa: John Jackson and Mark Haus TR (1993)  Val Licon and Phil Marshal FFA (1996)

content.description:
Taking the same start as "Mothers and Fathers" pedestal with the same few small cam options, Old Guys with the Shakes parts ways by continuing straight up.

The crux is between the two bolts on the climb and is thin climbing in the slab style.

A few pieces for the top in the .5"-1" range will protect the easy finish.
content.protection: Two bolts, singles from micro cams to 1", and the anchor shared with "Mothers and Fathers" as well as "Radical Right".
content.location: Just to the left of Mothers and Fathers.

climbs.name: Mothers And Fathers
climbs.fa: Val Lincon  Wendy Broadhead  Tom Grey  and, Lynne Zonge (1996)

content.description:
Climb a broken pedestal and follow the right slanting seam, largely using face holds with some locks and jams thrown in. The climb gains a small ledge before tackling the crux, a fairly incipient crack that relents to more face climbing shenanigans before a mantle to a large ledge.

The right facing dihedral with a mossy crack leads up from the final ledge to the anchors shared with "Old Guys with the Shakes" and "Radical Right".
content.protection: Singles of RPs and some microcams up to 3" will suffice.
content.location: Far right side of the crag, one of the first climbs you will encounter and the right most of the climbs on this particular face.
